From: Jeff Clune <jeffclune@...>
Subject: New Paper: Ontogeny tends to recapitulate phylogeny in digital organisms
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=467342474; y=ym7hct8k5Z4dBzlc1LszYjLUnxu4Fld8Sf-f4Hn5kGFdGajATvqz
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Hello all,

I wanted to let you know about a new paper I recently published=
. I did not use NEAT, but there are messages in the paper that relate to so=
me of the conversations we've had on this list.

Clune J, Pennock RT, Ofria=
 C, Lenski RE
Ontogeny tends to recapitulate phylogeny in digital organisms=
. 
The American Naturalist.  2012. 180: E54=96E63.
PDF: http://jeffclune.co=
m/publications/2012-CluneEtAl-OntegenyRecapitulatesPhylogeny-AmNat.pdf
Popu=
lar press writeup of the paper: http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/0=
8/120810133155.htm

The first relevant subject regards evolving good repres=
entations. The work of Joel, Ken, and colleagues has shown some interesting=
 things regarding when we can expect bad representations, such as in target=
-based search, where evolution keeps hacking in/bolting on new things that =
happen to work, and never takes the time to redesign from the ground up (or=
 even at middle levels). Nature, however, does something similar (though pe=
rhaps to a much lesser degree): vestigial organs and developmental stages h=
ang around, including intermediate developmental forms that are built and t=
hen dissolve entirely. In this paper we looked into whether we could see ev=
idence of that "bolting on" in Avida, a digital evolution platform that is =
not target-based in that it does not have an explicit fitness function. We =
found evidence for bolting on, just as we would expect from the existence o=
f vestigial developmental stages in biological organisms: new functionality=
 tended to appear later in the development of an organism, because mutation=
s that changed things more fundamentally/deeper in the representation were =
more likely to be deleterious and were more quickly weeded out by selection=
. I think the lesson is that this bolting on process is largely inevitable,=
 though I think it is a fascinating question whether it is less of an issue=
 in divergent search vs. convergent search. 

A second issue related to thi=
s list is that, because evolution tends to quickly select away mutations th=
at deeply change representations, it is likely a good idea to have somethin=
g like the genomic diversity protection in NEAT. Because recent work has sh=
own that phenotypic/behavioral diversity is more effective than genotypic d=
iversity, many people may be switching to phenotypic diversity and abandoni=
ng genomic diversity: this work suggests that both may be important. For ex=
ample, mutations that affect a representation deeply may initially hurt the=
 organism's ability to do something behaviorally different/interesting, for=
 the same reason that such mutations hurts fitness (e.g. they cripple the o=
rganism). Protecting that innovation for a while may thus pay off.  In othe=
r words, because selection will quickly work to eliminate deep changes, we =
should probably protect them for a while if we want to see better represent=
ations emerge.  

In the paper, we focus on an interesting consequence of b=
olting on: if new functionality is added to the end of an organism's life, =
then the order that an organism develops will tend to contain information a=
bout the order that traits evolved in its lineage, and vice-versa. That hel=
ps settle an age old debate by showing that "ontogeny tends to recapitulate=
 phylogeny". 

Please let me know if you have any questions or comments. 

=
Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Visiting Scientist
Cornell University
jeffclune@c=
ornell.edu
jeffclune.com
